title: Creating a new Learner
text: train function takes Task input must return model, .e. R object allows learner make predictions. want translate following call rpart::rpart() code can used inside .train() method. First, write something works completely without mlr3: need pass formula notation mpg ~ ., data hyperparameters. get hyperparameters, call self$param_set$get_values(tag = "train") thereby query parameters using "train". , dataset extracted Task. learner property "weights", insert weights task . obtain formula task using task$formula() access training data using task$data(). Last, call upstream function rpart::rpart() data pass hyperparameters via argument .args using mlr3misc::invoke() function. latter simply optimized version .call() use within mlr3 ecosystem. return value method available $model slot trained learner. point, explanation difference public method $train() private method $.train() order. former essentially calls latter additionally performs checks tasks every learner. holds predict method.
code: data = mtcars model = rpart::rpart(mpg ~ ., data = mtcars, xval = 0) .train = function(task) {   pv = self$param_set$get_values(tags = "train")   if ("weights" %in% task$properties) {     pv$weights = task$weights$weight   }   formula = task$formula()   data = task$data()   invoke(     rpart::rpart,     formula = formula,     data = data,     .args = pv   ) }

title: Creating a new Learner
text: internal method $.predict() also operates Task well fitted model created $train() call previously stored self$model. return value must contain required information produce mlr3::Prediction object returned $predict() called learner. proceed analogously previous section. start version without mlr3 objects continue replace objects reached desired interface: Next, transition data Task construct list return type requested user. stored $predict_type slot learner class. regr.rpart_simple learner implementing one predict type, take value self$predict_type account. , e.g., regression learners predict types "response" "se" classification learners predict types "response" "prob", predict method must return prediction requested user. final $.predict() method , omit pv line parameters "predict" tag keep consistent: Beware rely column order data returned task$data() order columns may different order columns $.train(). newdata line ensures ordering calling order train!
code: # inputs: task = tsk("mtcars") self = list(model = rpart::rpart(task$formula(), data = task$data())) data = mtcars  # response prediction response = predict(self$model, newdata = data) .predict = function(task) {   pv = self$param_set$get_values(tags = "predict")   # ensure same column order in train and predict   newdata = mlr3extralearners:::ordered_features(task, self)   response = invoke(predict, self$model, newdata = newdata, .args = pv)   list(response = unname(response)) }

title: Creating a new Learner
text: Specific learner implementations free implement additional getters ease access certain parts model inherited subclasses. methods standardized mlr3, c.f. Learner documentation. one standardized extractors, custom code might written return value comply mlr3 standards (see Learner documentation). specified earlier learner property "importance", implement public $importance() method. access $model slot learner training return one fields. $importance() method standardized, must return importance scores sorted numeric vector, names features.
code: importance = function() {   if (is.null(self$model)) {     stopf("No model stored")   }   # importance is only present if there is at least on split   if (is.null(self$model$variable.importance)) {     importance = set_names(numeric())   } else {     importance = sort(self$model$variable.importance, decreasing = TRUE)   }   return(importance) }

title: Creating a new Learner
text: learner created, write tests verify correctness. also implementing learner use, absolutely required want contribute new learner mlr3extralearners. Besides manual tests, mlr3 package also provides automatic tests check learner satisfies basic sanity checks implements available parameters upstream function. manual page functions can accessed via ?mlr_test_helpers. bare-bone check can just try run simple $train() call. runs without erroring, ’s good start!
code: task = tsk("mtcars") learner = LearnerRegrRpartSimple$new() learner$train(task) p = learner$predict(task)  p$score(msr("regr.mse")) ## regr.mse  ## 9.127693 learner$importance() ##       cyl      disp        hp        wt      qsec        vs      carb      gear  ## 724.18935 721.08062 702.29023 573.72817 442.05737 395.01237  31.36333  15.68167

title: Creating a new Learner
text: ensure learner able handle kinds different properties feature types, written “autotest” checks learner different combinations . addition autotest also check learner properties using expect_learner(). See section run_autotest expect_learner ?mlr_test_helpers explanation. functions mlr3 namespace, source ./testthat subfolder installed mlr3 package Note implementing survival learners, must also source help files mlr3proba package. now perform autotest. setting expect_learner(..., check_man = FALSE), disable test verifies correct manual page exists, relevant adding learner mlr3extralearners.
code: lapply(list.files(system.file("testthat", package = "mlr3"), pattern = "^helper.*\\.[rR]", full.names = TRUE), source) # mlr3proba # lapply(list.files(system.file("testthat", package = "mlr3proba"), pattern = "^helper.*\\.[rR]", full.names = TRUE), source) library(testthat) test_that("autotest", {   learner = LearnerRegrRpartSimple$new()    # basic learner properties   expect_learner(learner)    # you can skip tests using the `exclude` argument   result = run_autotest(learner)   expect_true(result, info = result$error) }) ## Test passed

title: Creating a new Learner
text: learners high number parameters easy miss creation new learner misspell parameter. Therefore written “Parameter Check” can used check parameters correctly implemented. See section run_paramtest ?mlr_test_helpers explanation. “Parameter Check” compares parameters mlr3 ParamSet arguments available upstream function called $train() $predict(). $.train() method either calls multiple functions, , e.g., ... arguments passed control function (case ), list functions can passed parameter test. test comes exclude argument used exclude explain certain arguments upstream function within ParamSet learner. likely required learners common arguments like x, target data handled mlr3 interface therefore included within ParamSet. However, might parameters need excluded, example: Type dependent parameters, .e. parameters apply classification regression learners. Parameters actually deprecated upstream package therefore included mlr3 ParamSet. excluded parameters comment justifying exclusion. example, final paramtest script looks like:
code: test_that("paramtest", {   learner = LearnerRegrRpartSimple$new()    exclude = c("formula", "data", "weights", "subset", "na.action", "method", "model",     "x", "y", "parms", "control", "cost", "keep_model")   result = run_paramtest(learner, list(rpart::rpart, rpart::rpart.control), exclude, tag = "train")   expect_true(result, info = result$error)    exclude = c(     "object", # handled internally     "newdata", # handled internally     "type", # handled internally     "na.action", # handled internally     "model" # not implemented   )   result = run_paramtest(learner, rpart:::predict.rpart, exclude, tag = "predict")   expect_true(result, info = result$error) }) ## Test passed

title: Creating a new Learner
text: adding Learner mlr3extralearners additional requirements satisfied: Adding line .extralrns_dict$add("<learner-id>", function() <LearnerName>$new()) bottom learner file add learner learners Dictionary. Add learner dependencies Suggests (e.g. Imports) DESCRIPTION file. learner must properly documented. using mlr3extralearners::create_learner() automatically generated. Otherwise can use adapt documentation already implemented learner. Conforming mlr3 style guide. tests must pass CI (also check CodeFactor results). Update NEWS.md file describe added learner. title: Extra Learners For mlr3
text: mlr3extralearners contains learners mlr3 mlr3learners core packages. overview learners within mlr3verse can found . mlr3extralearners lives GitHub CRAN. can install package follows: Alternatively, can add following .Rprofile, allows install mlr3extralearners via install.packages(). Note install development version.
code: # latest GitHub release remotes::install_github("mlr-org/mlr3extralearners@*release")  # development version remotes::install_github("mlr-org/mlr3extralearners") # .Rprofile options(repos = c(   mlrorg = "https://mlr-org.r-universe.dev",   CRAN = "https://cloud.r-project.org/" ))

title: Extra Learners For mlr3
text: package includes functionality detecting required packages installed use learner, ships function install_learner can install required learner dependencies.
code: lrn("regr.gbm") #> Warning: Package 'gbm' required but not installed for Learner 'regr.gbm' #> <LearnerRegrGBM:regr.gbm>: Gradient Boosting #> * Model: - #> * Parameters: keep.data=FALSE, n.cores=1 #> * Packages: mlr3, mlr3extralearners, gbm #> * Predict Types:  [response] #> * Feature Types: integer, numeric, factor, ordered #> * Properties: importance, missings, weights  install_learners("regr.gbm")  lrn("regr.gbm") #> <LearnerRegrGBM:regr.gbm>: Gradient Boosting #> * Model: - #> * Parameters: keep.data=FALSE, n.cores=1 #> * Packages: mlr3, mlr3extralearners, gbm #> * Predict Types:  [response] #> * Feature Types: integer, numeric, factor, ordered #> * Properties: importance, missings, weights

title: Create a New Learner — create_learner
text: Helper function create template learner, well test parameter test. details see mlr3book.

title: Create a New Learner — create_learner
code: create_learner(   path = ".",   classname,   type,   key = tolower(classname),   algorithm,   package,   caller,   feature_types,   predict_types,   properties,   gh_name = "Unknown",   label = toproper(algorithm),   data_formats = "data.table" )

title: Create a New Learner — create_learner
text: path (character(1)) path folder. files created. case folder R package, learner file create path/R test files created path/tests/testthat. Otherwise files created path. classname (character(1)) Suffix R6 class name passed LearnerType 'classname'. type (character(1)) See mlr3::mlr_reflections$task_types$type. key (character(1)) key learner, provided defaults classname lower case. combination type creates learner's id. algorithm (character(1)) Brief description algorithm, like "Linear Model" "Random Forest". used title help package label (label provided). package (character(1)) Package learner implemented. caller character(1) Training function called upstream package. feature_types (character()) Feature types can handled learner, see mlr3::mlr_reflections$task_feature_types. predict_types (character()) Prediction types can made learner, see mlr3::mlr_reflections$learner_predict_types. properties (character()) Properties can handled learner, see mlr3::mlr_reflections$learner_properties. gh_name (character(1)) GitHub handle, used add maintainer learner. Defaults "Unknown". label (character(1)) Label learner, default value parameter algorithm. data_formats (character(1)) data format learner can deal (see mlr_reflections$data_formats). Default "data.table" rarely changes.

title: Create a New Learner — create_learner
code: if (FALSE) { path = tempfile() dir.create(path) create_learner(   path = path,   classname = "Rpart",   type = "classif",   key = "rpart",   algorithm = "Decision Tree",   package = "rpart",   caller = "rpart",   feature_types = c("logical", "integer", "numeric", "factor", "ordered"),   predict_types = c("response", "prob"),   properties = c("importance", "missings", "multiclass", "twoclass", "weights"),   gh_name = "RaphaelS1",   label = "Regression and Partition Tree",   data_formats = "data.table" ) }

title: LiblineaR Classification Learner — mlr_learners_classif.liblinear
text: L2 regularized support vector classification. Calls LiblineaR::LiblineaR() LiblineaR.

title: LiblineaR Classification Learner — mlr_learners_classif.liblinear
text: Type SVC depends type argument: 0 – L2-regularized logistic regression (primal) 1 - L2-regularized L2-loss support vector classification (dual) 3 - L2-regularized L1-loss support vector classification (dual) 2 – L2-regularized L2-loss support vector classification (primal) 4 – Support vector classification Crammer Singer 5 - L1-regularized L2-loss support vector classification 6 - L1-regularized logistic regression 7 - L2-regularized logistic regression (dual) number records > number features, type = 2 faster type = 1 (Hsu et al. 2003). Note probabilistic predictions available types 0, 6, 7. default epsilon value depends type parameter, see LiblineaR::LiblineaR.

Classification Model-based Recursive Partitioning Learner — mlr_learners_classif.mob
code: library(mlr3) logit_ = function(y, x, start = NULL, weights = NULL, offset = NULL, ...) {   glm(y ~ 1, family = binomial, start = start, ...) } learner = LearnerClassifMob$new() learner$param_set$values$rhs = "." learner$param_set$values$fit = logit_ learner$param_set$values$additional = list(maxit = 100) learner$feature_types = c("logical", "integer", "numeric", "factor", "ordered") learner$properties = c("twoclass", "weights")  predict_fun = function(object, newdata, task, .type) {   p = unname(predict(object, newdata = newdata, type = "response"))   levs = task$levels(task$target_names)[[1L]]    if (.type == "response") {     ifelse(p < 0.5, levs[1L], levs[2L])   } else {     prob_vector_to_matrix(p, levs)   } } task = tsk("breast_cancer") learner$param_set$values$predict_fun = predict_fun ids = partition(task) learner$train(task, row_ids = ids$train) learner$predict(task, row_ids = ids$test) #> <PredictionClassif> for 226 observations: #>     row_ids     truth  response #>           1    benign    benign #>           2    benign malignant #>          10    benign    benign #> ---                             #>         643 malignant malignant #>         654 malignant malignant #>         683 malignant malignant

text: mtry: hyperparameter can alternatively set via added hyperparameter mtry.ratio mtry = max(ceiling(mtry.ratio * n_features), 1). Note mtry mtry.ratio mutually exclusive. sampsize: hyperparameter can alternatively set via added hyperparameter sampsize.ratio sampsize = max(ceiling(sampsize.ratio * n_obs), 1). Note sampsize sampsize.ratio mutually exclusive. cores: value set option rf.cores training set 1 default.

title: Classification Random Planted Forest Learner — mlr_learners_classif.rpf
text: loss: Actual default: "L2". Initial value: "exponential". Reason change: Using "L2" ("L1") loss guarantee predictions valid probabilities akin linear predictor GLM.

title: Classification Random Planted Forest Learner — mlr_learners_classif.rpf
text: max_interaction: hyperparameter can alternatively set via max_interaction_ratio max_interaction = max(ceiling(max_interaction_ratio * n_features), 1). parameter max_interaction_limit can optionally set upper bound, max_interaction_ratio * min(n_features, max_interaction_limit) used instead. analogous mtry.ratio classif.ranger, max_interaction_limit additional constraint. parameter max_interaction_limit initialized Inf.

Regression Model-based Recursive Partitioning Learner — mlr_learners_regr.mob
code: library(mlr3) lm_ = function(y, x, start = NULL, weights = NULL, offset = NULL, ...) {   lm(y ~ 1, ...) } learner = LearnerRegrMob$new() learner$param_set$values$rhs = "." learner$param_set$values$fit = lm_ learner$feature_types = c("logical", "integer", "numeric", "factor", "ordered")  predict_fun = function(object, newdata, task, .type) {   preds = predict(object, newdata = newdata, type = "response", se.fit = TRUE)   cbind(preds$fit, preds$se.fit) } learner$param_set$values$predict_fun = predict_fun task = tsk("mtcars") ids = partition(task) learner$train(task, row_ids = ids$train) learner$predict(task, row_ids = ids$test) #> <PredictionRegr> for 11 observations: #>     row_ids truth response #>           1  21.0 24.83000 #>           5  18.7 15.03636 #>           9  22.8 24.83000 #> ---                        #>          29  15.8 24.83000 #>          18  32.4 24.83000 #>          28  30.4 24.83000

Note sampsize sampsize.ratio mutually exclusive. cores: value set option rf.cores training set 1 default.

title: Survival Bayesian Additive Regression Trees Learner — mlr_learners_surv.bart
text: Fits Bayesian Additive Regression Trees (BART) learner right-censored survival data. Calls BART::mc.surv.bart() BART.

title: Survival Bayesian Additive Regression Trees Learner — mlr_learners_surv.bart
text: Two types prediction returned learner: distr: 3d survival array observations 1st dimension, time points 2nd posterior draws 3rd dimension. crank: expected mortality using mlr3proba::.surv_return. parameter .curve decides posterior draw (3rd dimension) used calculation expected mortality. Note median posterior default used calculation survival measures require distr prediction, see info PredictionSurv.

title: Survival Bayesian Additive Regression Trees Learner — mlr_learners_surv.bart
text: mc.cores initialized 1 avoid threading conflicts future.

title: Survival Bayesian Additive Regression Trees Learner — mlr_learners_surv.bart
text: quiet allows suppress messages generated wrapped C++ code. initialized TRUE. importance allows choose type importance. Default count, see documentation method $importance() details. .curve allows choose posterior draw used calculation crank prediction. (0,1) taken quantile curves otherwise greater 1 taken curve index, can also 'mean'. default median posterior used, .e. .curve 0.5.

text: Two types importance scores supported based value parameter importance: prob: mean selection probability feature trees, extracted slot varprob.mean. sparse = FALSE (default), fixed constant. Recommended use option sparse = TRUE. count: mean observed count feature trees (average number times feature used tree decision rule across posterior draws), extracted slot varcount.mean. default importance scores. cases, higher values signify important variables.

what: Survival Cox Model with Likelihood Based Boosting Learner — mlr_learners_surv.coxboost
title: Survival Cox Model with Likelihood Based Boosting Learner — mlr_learners_surv.coxboost
text: Fit Survival Cox model likelihood based boosting algorithm. Calls CoxBoost::CoxBoost() package 'CoxBoost'.

title: Survival Cox Model with Likelihood Based Boosting Learner — mlr_learners_surv.coxboost
text: Use LearnerSurvCoxboost LearnerSurvCVCoxboost Cox boosting without internal cross-validation boosting step number, respectively. Tuning using internal optimizer LearnerSurvCVCoxboost may efficient tuning stepno . However, tuning multiple hyperparameters, mlr3tuning LearnerSurvCoxboost likely give better results. Three prediction types returned learner, using internal predict.CoxBoost() function: lp: vector linear predictors (relative risk scores), one per observation. crank: lp. distr: 2d survival matrix, observations rows time points columns. internal transformation uses Breslow estimator compose survival distributions lp predictions.

what: Survival Cox Model with Cross-Validation Likelihood Based Boosting Learner — mlr_learners_surv.cv_coxboost
title: Survival Cox Model with Cross-Validation Likelihood Based Boosting Learner — mlr_learners_surv.cv_coxboost
text: Fits survival Cox model using likelihood based boosting interal cross-validation number steps. Calls CoxBoost::CoxBoost() CoxBoost::cv.CoxBoost() package 'CoxBoost'.

title: Survival Cox Model with Cross-Validation Likelihood Based Boosting Learner — mlr_learners_surv.cv_coxboost
text: Use LearnerSurvCoxboost LearnerSurvCVCoxboost Cox boosting without internal cross-validation boosting step number, respectively. Tuning using internal optimizer LearnerSurvCVCoxboost may efficient tuning stepno . However, tuning multiple hyperparameters, mlr3tuning LearnerSurvCoxboost likely give better results. penalty == "optimCoxBoostPenalty" CoxBoost::optimCoxBoostPenalty used determine penalty value used CoxBoost::cv.CoxBoost. Three prediction types returned learner, using internal predict.CoxBoost() function: lp: vector linear predictors (relative risk scores), one per observation. crank: lp. distr: 2d survival matrix, observations rows time points columns. internal transformation uses Breslow estimator compose survival distributions lp predictions.

title: Cross-Validated GLM with Elastic Net Regularization Survival Learner — mlr_learners_surv.cv_glmnet
text: learner returns two prediction types: lp: vector linear predictors (relative risk scores), one per observation. Calculated using glmnet::predict.cv.glmnet(). distr: survival matrix two dimensions, observations represented rows time points columns. Calculated using glmnet::survfit.cv.glmnet(). Parameters stype ctype relate lp predictions transformed survival predictions described survival::survfit.coxph(). default Breslow estimator used.

what: GLM with Elastic Net Regularization Survival Learner — mlr_learners_surv.glmnet
title: GLM with Elastic Net Regularization Survival Learner — mlr_learners_surv.glmnet
text: Generalized linear models elastic net regularization. Calls glmnet::glmnet() package glmnet.

title: GLM with Elastic Net Regularization Survival Learner — mlr_learners_surv.glmnet
text: learner returns two prediction types: lp: vector linear predictors (relative risk scores), one per observation. Calculated using glmnet::predict.coxnet(). distr: survival matrix two dimensions, observations represented rows time points columns. Calculated using glmnet::survfit.coxnet(). Parameters stype ctype relate lp predictions transformed survival predictions described survival::survfit.coxph(). default Breslow estimator used. Caution: learner different learners calling glmnet::cv.glmnet() use internal optimization parameter lambda. Instead, lambda needs tuned user (e.g., via mlr3tuning). lambda tuned, glmnet trained tuning iteration. fitting whole path lambdas efficient, done default glmnet::glmnet(), tuning/selecting parameter prediction time (using parameter s) currently supported mlr3 (least efficient manner). Tuning s parameter , therefore, currently discouraged. data ..d. efficiency key, recommend using respective auto-tuning counterpart mlr_learners_surv.cv_glmnet(). However, situations applicable, usually data imbalanced ..d. (longitudinal, time-series) tuning requires custom resampling strategies (blocked design, stratification).

title: Survival Fully Parametric Learner — mlr_learners_surv.parametric
Survival Fully Parametric Learner — mlr_learners_surv.parametric
text: learner allows choose distribution model form compose predicted survival probability distribution. predict method implemented survivalmodels::predict.parametric(). implementation efficient composition distributions survival::predict.survreg(). Three types prediction returned learner: lp: vector linear predictors (relative risk scores), one per test observation. lp predicted using formula \(lp = X\beta\) \(X\) variables test data set \(\beta\) fitted coefficients. crank: lp. distr: survival matrix two dimensions, observations represented rows time points columns. distribution distr composed using lp predictions specifying model form form hyper-parameter. follows, respective survival functions: Accelerated Failure Time (aft) $$S(t) = S_0(\frac{t}{exp(lp)})$$ Proportional Hazards (ph) $$S(t) = S_0(t)^{exp(lp)}$$ Proportional Odds (po) $$S(t) = \frac{S_0(t)}{exp(-lp) + (1-exp(-lp)) S_0(t)}$$ Tobit (tobit) $$S(t) = 1 - \Phi((t - lp)/s)$$ \(S_0\) estimated baseline survival distribution (case given parametric form), \(lp\) predicted linear predictor, \(\Phi\) cdf N(0, 1) distribution, \(s\) fitted scale parameter. Whilst combination distribution model form possible, mean necessarily create sensible interpretable prediction. following combinations 'sensible' (note ones mostly used literature): dist = "gaussian"; form = "tobit"; dist = "weibull"; form = "ph"; (fairly used) dist = "exponential"; form = "ph"; dist = "weibull"; form = "aft"; (fairly used, default option) dist = "exponential"; form = "aft"; dist = "loglogistic"; form = "aft"; (fairly used) dist = "lognormal"; form = "aft"; dist = "loglogistic"; form = "po";

title: Survival Random Forest SRC Learner — mlr_learners_surv.rfsrc
text: Random survival forest. Calls randomForestSRC::rfsrc() randomForestSRC.

title: Survival Random Forest SRC Learner — mlr_learners_surv.rfsrc
text: randomForestSRC::predict.rfsrc() returns cumulative hazard function (chf) survival function (surv) uses different estimators derive . chf uses bootstrapped Nelson-Aalen estimator, (Ishwaran, 2008) whereas surv uses bootstrapped Kaplan-Meier estimator. choice estimator use given extra estimator hyper-parameter, default nelson.

title: Survival Random Forest SRC Learner — mlr_learners_surv.rfsrc
text: Learner can instantiated via dictionary mlr_learners associated sugar function lrn():

title: Survival Random Forest SRC Learner — mlr_learners_surv.rfsrc
text: Task type: “surv” Predict Types: “crank”, “distr” Feature Types: “logical”, “integer”, “numeric”, “factor” Required Packages: mlr3, mlr3proba, mlr3extralearners, randomForestSRC, pracma

title: Survival Random Forest SRC Learner — mlr_learners_surv.rfsrc
text: mtry: hyperparameter can alternatively set via added hyperparameter mtry.ratio mtry = max(ceiling(mtry.ratio * n_features), 1). Note mtry mtry.ratio mutually exclusive. sampsize: hyperparameter can alternatively set via added hyperparameter sampsize.ratio sampsize = max(ceiling(sampsize.ratio * n_obs), 1). Note sampsize sampsize.ratio mutually exclusive. cores: value set option rf.cores training set 1 default.

title: Survival Random Forest SRC Learner — mlr_learners_surv.rfsrc

title: Survival Support Vector Machine Learner — mlr_learners_surv.svm
text: Survival support vector machine. Calls survivalsvm::survivalsvm() survivalsvm.

title: Survival Support Vector Machine Learner — mlr_learners_surv.svm
text: Four possible SVMs can implemented, dependent type parameter. correspond predicting survival time via regression (regression), predicting continuous rank (vanbelle1, vanbelle2), hybrid two (hybrid). Whichever type chosen determines crank predict type calculated, case can considered valid continuous ranking. makediff3 recommended using type = "hybrid".

what: Extreme Gradient Boosting AFT Survival Learner — mlr_learners_surv.xgboost.aft
title: Extreme Gradient Boosting AFT Survival Learner — mlr_learners_surv.xgboost.aft
text: eXtreme Gradient Boosting regression using Accelerated Failure Time objective. Calls xgboost::xgb.train() package xgboost objective set survival:aft eval_metric aft-nloglik default.

title: Extreme Gradient Boosting AFT Survival Learner — mlr_learners_surv.xgboost.aft
text: learner returns three prediction types: response: estimated survival time \(T\) test observation. lp: vector linear predictors (relative risk scores), one per observation, estimated \(-log(T)\). Higher survival time denotes lower risk. crank: lp.

title: Extreme Gradient Boosting AFT Survival Learner — mlr_learners_surv.xgboost.aft
text: compute GPUs, first need compile xgboost link CUDA. See https://xgboost.readthedocs.io/en/stable/build.html#building--gpu-support.

title: Extreme Gradient Boosting AFT Survival Learner — mlr_learners_surv.xgboost.aft
text: nrounds initialized 1. nthread initialized 1 avoid conflicts parallelization via future. verbose initialized 0.

title: Extreme Gradient Boosting AFT Survival Learner — mlr_learners_surv.xgboost.aft
text: Early stopping can used find optimal number boosting rounds. early_stopping_set parameter controls set used monitor performance. default, early_stopping_set = "none" disables early stopping. Set early_stopping_set = "test" monitor performance model test set training. test set early stopping can set "test" row role mlr3::Task. Additionally, range must set performance must increase early_stopping_rounds maximum number boosting rounds nrounds. resampling, test set automatically applied mlr3::Resampling. using test set early stopping can potentially bias performance scores. title: mlr3extralearners 0.8.0
text: Added surv.xgboost.cox surv.xgboost.aft separate survival learners. distr prediction cox xgboost learner now estimated via Breslow default aft xgboost now addition response prediction (survival time) Ported surv.parametric code survivalmodels, changed type parameter form avoid conflict survivalmodels’s default parameter list Fix: Replace hardcoded VectorDistributions partykit flexsurv survival learners survival matrices (Matdist) (thanks @bblodfon) Feat: Add discrete parameter surv.parametric learner return Matdist survival predictions Added method selected_features() CoxBoost survival learners (thanks @bblodfon) Added Random Planted Forest Learner (thanks @jemus42) re-added catboost learner requested (previously removed installation issues) surv.ranger now receives parameters $predict() (thanks @jemus42) Feature: Learner surv.bart added (thanks @bblodfon) Parameters lrn("surv.aorsf") updated (thanks @bcjaeger) Various minor doc improvements Added distr predict type surv.cv_glmnet surv.glmnet learners (thanks @bblodfon) Feat: Added many new WEKA learners (thanks @damirpolat) Fix: F params IBk learner interdependent (can TRUE F FALSE vice versa). Combined one factor param weight two levels – F. Fix: U must FALSE S tunable J48 learner. Compatibility upcoming ‘paradox’ release.

title: mlr3extralearners 0.7.1

title: mlr3extralearners 0.7.0
text: Add new parameters lightgbm learners Add feature type "factor" gam learners Add new parameter min.bucket ranger Remove catboost learner (developers don’t properly take care R package) Add argument nthreads dbarts learners; set verbose FALSE default (thanks @ck37) Add new parameters prioritylasso Fix: available levels parameter imbalanced random forest (typo)

title: mlr3extralearners 0.2.0
text: dist = "logistic" removed surv.parametric unclear previously predicting. Added type = "tobit" dist = "gaussian" predictions can correspond survival::survreg. Added LearnerRegrGlm unique key regr.glm package stats, allows users change family hyperparameter fitting generalized linear regression models. Minor internal changes Removed keeptrees parameter classif.bart forced internally Fixed incorrect response probability predictions classif.bart Added hyper-parameters classif.earth regr.earth Added se predict type regr.earth Fixed predictions regr.knn classif.knn
